questions.q: What is a process in an operating system?
questions.explanation: A program is a passive entity (like an executable file), while a process is an active entity that is currently in execution[cite: 5].
options: A passive entity stored on disk
An active instance of a program in execution
A section of memory containing data

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT part of a process's memory layout?
questions.explanation: The memory layout of a process includes the text section, stack, data section, and heap[cite: 3].  The program counter is a register that tracks the current activity[cite: 3].

questions.q: When a process is waiting to be assigned to a processor, it is in the _____ state.
questions.explanation: The 'ready' state means the process is waiting to be assigned to a processor[cite: 5].

questions.q: Which data structure contains all information needed by the OS to manage a process?
questions.explanation: The Process Control Block (PCB) contains information associated with each process, such as its state, program counter, and CPU registers[cite: 6].

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of the long-term scheduler (job scheduler)?
questions.explanation: The long-term scheduler selects which processes should be brought into the ready queue and controls the degree of multiprogramming[cite: 13].
options: To select which process runs on the CPU next
To control the degree of multiprogramming by bringing processes into memory

questions.q: Which scheduler is invoked most frequently?
questions.explanation: The short-term scheduler is invoked frequently, often every few milliseconds[cite: 13].

questions.q: The act of saving the state of an old process and loading the saved state of a new process is called a _____.
questions.explanation: This process is known as a context switch[cite: 16].

questions.q: In a process tree, the original process that creates another process is called the _____.
questions.explanation: The creator is called the parent process[cite: 18].

questions.q: In UNIX, which system call is used to create a new process that is a copy of the calling process?
questions.explanation: The fork() system call creates a new process in UNIX[cite: 20].

questions.q: What does the exec() system call do in UNIX?
questions.explanation: The exec() system call is used to replace the process's memory space with a new program[cite: 20].
options: Replaces the current process's memory space with a new program
Waits for a child process to finish

questions.q: A process that has finished execution but whose parent has not yet called wait() is known as a _____.
questions.explanation: A process is called a zombie if its parent has not yet called wait()[cite: 28].

questions.q: Which of the following is a reason for processes to cooperate?
questions.explanation: Reasons for cooperating processes include information sharing, computation speedup, modularity, and convenience[cite: 29].
options: To simplify the operating system kernel

questions.q: Which IPC (Interprocess Communication) method is generally faster?
questions.explanation: Shared memory is generally faster because it is under the control of user processes and doesn't require the operating system for every data transfer[cite: 40].

questions.q: In the Producer-Consumer problem using shared memory, what is the purpose of the in and out variables?
questions.explanation: In a shared-memory solution, 'in' points to the next free position in the buffer, and 'out' points to the first full position[cite: 33, 34].
options: To count the total items produced
To point to the next empty and full buffer slots
To synchronize access to the CPU

questions.q: In message passing, when both send and receive operations are blocking, it is called a _____.
questions.explanation: If both send and receive are blocking, it results in a rendezvous between the sender and receiver[cite: 52].

questions.q: Which of the following buffering strategies in message passing means the sender must always wait for the receiver?
questions.explanation: Zero capacity means the queue length is zero; thus, the sender must wait for the receiver to perform a rendezvous[cite: 56].

questions.q: In Indirect Communication via mailboxes, which of the following is true?
questions.explanation: In indirect communication, processes communicate only if they share a common mailbox[cite: 47].
options: Processes must name each other explicitly.
A link is associated with exactly one pair of processes.
Processes communicate only if they share a common mailbox.

questions.q: What is a Socket in network communication?
questions.explanation: A socket is defined as an endpoint for communication, combining an IP address and a port number[cite: 64].
options: A physical connector on a computer
An endpoint for communication, defined by an IP address and port number
A type of shared memory region
A system call for process creation

questions.q: Which port number range is reserved for well-known services?
questions.explanation: All ports below 1024 are considered 'well-known' and are used for standard services[cite: 64].

questions.q: What is the role of a Stub in Remote Procedure Call (RPC)?
questions.explanation: Stubs act as a client-side proxy for the actual procedure on the server[cite: 66].
options: To act as a client-side proxy for the remote procedure
To provide shared memory for communication
To schedule processes on the server

questions.q: Ordinary Pipes in UNIX require which relationship between communicating processes?
questions.explanation: Ordinary pipes require a parent-child relationship between the communicating processes[cite: 72].
options: They must be on different computers.
They must have a parent-child relationship.
They must be threads of the same process.

questions.q: Which of the following is an advantage of Named Pipes over Ordinary Pipes?
questions.explanation: Named pipes can be accessed without a parent-child relationship[cite: 73].
options: They allow communication between unrelated processes.

questions.q: In the Chrome browser architecture, which process is responsible for rendering a web page?
questions.explanation: The renderer process is responsible for rendering web pages and handling HTML/Javascript[cite: 28].

questions.q: The Mach operating system uses which method as its primary IPC mechanism?
questions.explanation: Mach communication is message-based; even system calls are messages[cite: 60].
options: Message Passing (for everything, even system calls)

questions.q: Windows uses which facility for efficient message-passing IPC on the same system?
questions.explanation: Windows uses the Advanced Local Procedure Call (LPC) facility for message passing between processes on the same system[cite: 61].

questions.q: A process that spends more time doing computations than I/O is termed _____.
questions.explanation: A CPU-bound process spends more time doing computations and has few long CPU bursts[cite: 14].

questions.q: The medium-term scheduler is primarily involved in _____.
questions.explanation: The medium-term scheduler handles swapping processes in and out of memory to control the degree of multiprogramming[cite: 14].
options: Swapping processes in and out of memory

questions.q: In the Linux kernel, a process is represented by a structure called _____.
questions.explanation: In Linux, processes are represented by the C structure 'task_struct'[cite: 8].

questions.q: Which state transition is caused by a process making an I/O request?
questions.explanation: A process moves from the running state to the waiting state when it waits for an I/O or event wait[cite: 6].

questions.q: The wait() system call allows a parent process to _____.
questions.explanation: A parent process uses wait() to synchronize with and receive status data from a terminating child[cite: 22, 26].
options: Synchronize with the termination of a child
Send a message to another process

questions.q: A program is an active entity, while a process is a passive entity.
questions.explanation: It is the opposite: a program is passive, and a process is active[cite: 5].

questions.q: The heap segment of a process's memory is used for storing global variables.
questions.explanation: The data section stores global variables; the heap is for memory dynamically allocated during run time[cite: 3].

questions.q: A process in the 'waiting' state is waiting for an event such as I/O completion.
questions.explanation: The waiting state occurs when a process is waiting for some event (like I/O) to occur[cite: 5].

questions.q: The Process Control Block (PCB) is stored in a protected area of memory inaccessible to user processes.
questions.explanation: The PCB is managed by the operating system to maintain process information[cite: 6].

questions.q: The short-term scheduler is also known as the CPU scheduler.
questions.explanation: The short-term scheduler is another name for the CPU scheduler[cite: 13].

questions.q: An I/O-bound process typically has many short CPU bursts.
questions.explanation: I/O-bound processes spend more time doing I/O and have many short CPU bursts[cite: 13].

questions.q: Context switch time is considered pure overhead for the system.
questions.explanation: Context switching is overhead because the system does no useful work while switching[cite: 16].

questions.q: In process creation, the child process always shares all resources with its parent.
questions.explanation: Resource sharing is an option; they can share all, a subset, or no resources[cite: 18].

questions.q: The fork() system call in UNIX creates a new process that runs a different program from the start.
questions.explanation: fork() creates a duplicate of the parent; exec() is then used to load a different program[cite: 20].

questions.q: Cascading termination means when a child process terminates, all its parent processes are also terminated.
questions.explanation: Cascading termination means if a process terminates, all its children (and descendants) must also be terminated[cite: 24].

questions.q: A 'zombie' process consumes no significant system resources but retains an entry in the process table.
questions.explanation: A zombie process has finished but remains in the process table until its parent calls wait()[cite: 28].

questions.q: Cooperating processes cannot share logical address space (code and data).
questions.explanation: Cooperating processes can share data and affect each other, often through shared memory or message passing[cite: 29].

questions.q: Message passing is typically faster than shared memory for IPC because it avoids system calls.
questions.explanation: Shared memory is generally faster because message passing requires system calls and kernel intervention[cite: 40].

questions.q: In direct message passing, processes must explicitly name each other (e.g., send(P, message)).
questions.explanation: Direct communication requires explicit naming of the sender or receiver[cite: 46].

questions.q: A mailbox (port) can be associated with more than two processes in indirect communication.
questions.explanation: In indirect communication, a link may be associated with many processes that share the mailbox[cite: 48].

questions.q: In non-blocking send, the sending process is paused until the message is received.
questions.explanation: In a non-blocking send, the sender sends the message and continues immediately[cite: 52].

questions.q: Sockets can only be used for communication between processes on different computers over a network.
questions.explanation: Sockets can be used for communication on the same machine using the loopback address[cite: 64].

questions.q: The loopback address (127.0.0.1) is used for network communication with other hosts on the internet.
questions.explanation: The loopback address refers to the system on which the process is currently running[cite: 64].

questions.q: Remote Procedure Call (RPC) is designed to make a call to a procedure on a remote server appear as a local call.
questions.explanation: RPC abstracts procedure calls to make them appear like local calls[cite: 66].

questions.q: Named pipes (FIFOs) in UNIX can be used by processes that do not have a parent-child relationship.
questions.explanation: Named pipes do not require a parent-child relationship for communication[cite: 73].
